title: 111_hr3737
content: The Act may be cited as the "Small Business Microlending Expansion Act of 2009". It includes a Microloan Credit Building Initiative. Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act is amended to require intermediaries to provide credit reporting information to major credit agencies for borrowers, including payment activity on loans. The Small Business Act now requires intermediaries to provide credit reporting information to major agencies, including payment activity on loans. This allows intermediaries to share borrower information with credit reporting agencies through the Administration or independently. SEC. 3. FLEXIBLE CREDIT TERMS. Amends Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act to remove "short-term" from various paragraphs. SEC. 4. INCREASED PROGRAM PARTICIPATION. Section 7(m)(2) of the Small Business Act is amended to require individuals involved in making microloans to have at least 1 year of experience or 1 full-time employee with 3 years of experience. Section 7(m)(2) of the Small Business Act now mandates individuals making microloans to have 1 year of experience or 1 full-time employee with 3 years of experience. The Small Business Act requires individuals making microloans to have at least 3 years of experience in making microloans to small businesses, along with 1 year of experience providing intensive marketing, management, and technical assistance to borrowers. Alternatively, they can have 1 full-time employee with the required experience. The Small Business Act mandates individuals involved in microloans to have 3 years of experience in making microloans to small businesses and 1 year of experience in providing intensive marketing, management, and technical assistance to borrowers. Alternatively, they can have 1 full-time employee with the necessary experience. SEC. 5 increases the limit on intermediary borrowing from $750,000 to $1,000,000 and from $3,500,000 to $7,000,000. The Administrator may consider $7,000,000 as $10,000,000 if deemed appropriate. SEC. 6 expands borrower education assistance. SEC. 6 expands borrower education assistance by increasing the percentage from 25% to 35% in the Small Business Act. Section 7(m)(4) of the Small Business Act is amended to include a Young Entrepreneurs Program for providing technical assistance to young entrepreneurs in establishing or operating small businesses. Establish a program in the geographic area served by an intermediary to provide young entrepreneurs with technical assistance in establishing or operating a small business and acquiring financing for their activities. The program aims to assist young entrepreneurs in the geographic area served by the intermediary in acquiring financing for their small business activities. A young entrepreneur is defined as an individual aged 25 or younger who has resided in the area. A young entrepreneur, defined as an individual aged 25 or younger who has resided in the geographic area served by the intermediary for at least 2 years, is eligible for technical assistance under this program. A young entrepreneur receiving technical assistance must make a good faith effort to establish or operate a small business in the geographic area served by the intermediary. The young entrepreneur must make a good faith effort to establish or operate a small business in the geographic area served by the intermediary. If the entrepreneur receives a loan, repayment can be deferred for up to 6 months. If a small business established by a young entrepreneur receives a loan, repayment can be deferred for up to 6 months. SEC. 8. INTEREST RATES AND LOAN SIZE amended to increase loan size from $7,500 to $10,000 in various paragraphs. SEC. 9. REPORTING REQUIREMENT. Section 7(m) of the Small Business Act is amended to include a reporting requirement for the Administrator to submit an annual report to the House and Senate Committees on Small Business regarding the microloan program. The Administrator must submit an annual report to the House and Senate Committees on Small Business regarding the microloan program, including details on intermediary names, locations, loan and grant amounts, and non-Federal contributions. The annual report on the microloan program includes details on intermediary names, locations, loan and grant amounts, non-Federal contributions, and the number and amounts of microloans made to women entrepreneurs, low-income entrepreneurs, and business owners. The annual report on the microloan program includes details on intermediary names, locations, loan and grant amounts, non-Federal contributions, and the number and amounts of microloans made to women, low-income, veteran, disabled, and minority entrepreneurs and business owners. The annual report on the microloan program details the assistance provided by intermediaries to various groups including low-income, veteran, disabled, minority, and women entrepreneurs and business owners. The annual report on the microloan program details the marketing, management, and technical assistance provided by intermediaries to women, low-income, veteran, disabled, and minority entrepreneurs and business owners. The annual report on the microloan program includes details on the number of jobs created and retained, repayment history, and assistance provided to low-income, veteran, disabled, and minority entrepreneurs and business owners. The annual report on the microloan program includes information on jobs created and retained, repayment history, assistance provided, and success of businesses after receiving a microloan. SEC. 10. Surplus interest rate subsidy for businesses. The Administrator can provide grants to intermediaries to reduce interest rates for borrowers under this subsection. SEC. 11. Authorization of appropriations. Section 20 of the Small Business Act is amended to authorize the Administration to provide $80 million in technical assistance grants, $110 million in direct loans, and $10 million in interest assistance grants for fiscal years 2010 and 2011. For fiscal years 2010 and 2011, the Small Business Act authorizes $80 million in technical assistance grants, $110 million in direct loans, and $10 million in interest assistance grants. Authorization of appropriations is provided as necessary to carry out these provisions. SEC. 12. REGULATIONS. The Administrator must issue regulations within 180 days of the enactment of this Act to carry out its provisions.
